title: Conversation Quality Rubric
description: A rubric for scoring conversation quality based on key metrics.

criteria.name: Structure
criteria.description: Evaluates the organization and logical flow of the conversation.

levels.5: Excellent: The conversation has a flawless, logical structure. It includes a clear opening, a well-defined body, and a conclusive closing. The flow is natural and very easy to follow.
levels.4: Good: The conversation is well-structured with a clear sense of direction. There might be minor deviations, but they don't detract from the overall logical progression.
levels.3: Adequate: A basic structure is present, but some parts of the conversation may feel disorganized or difficult to follow. The transitions between topics may be abrupt.
levels.2: Poor: The conversation lacks a clear structure. It often jumps between topics haphazardly, making it difficult to track the main points.
levels.1: Very Poor: The conversation is completely disorganized and chaotic, with no discernible logical flow or structure.

criteria.name: Empathy
criteria.description: Evaluates the ability to understand, acknowledge, and validate the other person's feelings and perspective.

levels.5: Excellent: Consistently demonstrates deep understanding and validation of the other person's emotions and viewpoint. Responses are highly attuned and supportive.
levels.4: Good: Generally shows empathy and acknowledges the other person's feelings. There may be occasional lapses or less impactful empathic statements.
levels.3: Adequate: Acknowledges the other person's feelings, but often in a superficial or formulaic way. The emotional connection feels limited.
levels.2: Poor: Rarely shows empathy. May be dismissive or fail to recognize the emotional state of the other person.
levels.1: Very Poor: Complete lack of empathy. Actively invalidates or ignores the other person's feelings and perspective.

criteria.name: Focus
criteria.description: Evaluates the ability to stay on topic and maintain relevance to the conversation's goals.

levels.5: Excellent: Stays completely on topic. All contributions are directly relevant to the main purpose of the conversation.
levels.4: Good: Mostly focused on the topic, with only minor and brief digressions that do not disrupt the flow.
levels.3: Adequate: The main topic is addressed, but there are several noticeable or lengthy digressions that distract from the core subject.
levels.2: Poor: Frequently goes off-topic, making it difficult to follow the main thread of the conversation. The original purpose is often obscured.
levels.1: Very Poor: Constantly off-topic. The original purpose of the conversation is completely lost or ignored.

criteria.name: Clarity
criteria.description: Evaluates the clarity, precision, and understandability of the language used.

levels.5: Excellent: Language is consistently precise, unambiguous, and easy to understand. Avoids jargon or explains it effectively.
levels.4: Good: Generally clear and understandable communication. There may be minor instances of ambiguity or slightly confusing language.
levels.3: Adequate: Communication is generally understandable but requires some effort from the listener due to vagueness, jargon, or convoluted sentence structures.
levels.2: Poor: Communication is often unclear, ambiguous, or confusing, leading to misunderstandings.
levels.1: Very Poor: Communication is largely incomprehensible, muddled, or nonsensical.

common_levels.0: Complete failure to demonstrate the skill. The response is irrelevant, incomprehensible, or shows no attempt to engage with the metric.
